problem.markdown:
Dan mentions that computing has social implications. Consider the following example: At a time when computing is the new literacy, what significant challenge does the US face in its effort to maintain a robust computing workforce? ( ) Underproduction - i.e., schools aren't producing enough students to fill the projected number of job openings. ( ) Underrepresentation - i.e., the people going into computing don't represent the full diversity of the US. ( ) Lack of a presence in K-12 education - i.e., the number and quality of computing classes in high school (in aggregate) is abysmal. (x) All of the above ( ) None of the above
[explanation] Incredibly, ALL three are significant challenges! There's a movement called "CS10K" -- whose goal is to hire, prepare and engage 10,000 new high school teachers to teach a new Advanced Placement Computer Science: Principles course. CS10 (and the "Beauty and Joy of Computing") hopes to fix this by providing an exciting, empowering and engaging course that will introduce more students to this exciting field!
[explanation]
